Add rate-limiting tests: simulate bursts to verify 429 responses, retry-after headers, and graceful degradation.

Clarify and assert expected behavior for ambiguous cases: define and encode explicit acceptance criteria for requestedDate-only and no-parameter requests (should they return error, default, or multiple results?).
Add authorization role tests: include 403 scenarios where token is valid but lacks permissions, and test different auth scopes if applicable.
Add content-negotiation tests: send Accept: application/xml or missing Accept header and assert proper Content-Type handling or 406 responses as applicable.
Expand date tests: include timezone-aware dates, boundary inclusion/exclusion, DST transitions, and alternative ISO date formats to validate parsing and semantics.
Strengthen schema validation: assert all required Product fields, types, and nested structures per schema; add tests for unexpected/missing fields in the response.
Make performance tests concrete: define and enforce SLA thresholds, and run load tests with large datasets and pagination enabled to measure realistic behavior.
Combine security and load tests: run injection/xss fuzzing under load and assert no data leakage or degradation.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: POST /1.0/kb/catalog/xml - Upload the full catalog as XML

covered: Valid Payload: Multiple scenarios (TC01, TC02, TC03, TC04, TC05, TC13, TC24, TC28–TC30) verify successful creation with well-formed XML payloads and various header combinations.
Required Header Validation: Missing/empty X-Killbill-CreatedBy is tested (TC06, TC07).
Optional Headers: Reason/Comment presence/absence and extra/unexpected headers are exercised (TC01, TC02, TC03, TC11).
Malformed/Invalid Payloads: Malformed, partial/corrupted, whitespace-only XML and empty body are covered (TC08, TC09, TC18, TC23).
Content-Type Handling: Unsupported content type is tested (TC10).
Large Payloads: Very large payload handling is considered (TC12).
Duplicate/Conflict Behaviour: Duplicate version scenario is included (TC25) though expected outcome is left conditional to system behavior.
Error Conditions: Unauthorized and backend-unavailable flows are tested (TC14, TC16).
Security: Tests for malicious/unsupported content (e.g., XXE) are included (TC17).
Performance & Concurrency: Load/concurrency and timing checks are included (TC19, TC20).
Regression/Backward Compatibility: Known-bug payload and legacy-client payload tests exist (TC21, TC22).
Encoding & Special Characters: Unicode/special characters and different encodings are covered (TC24, TC29).
Boundary Values: Boundary value testing for fields is included (TC30).
Location/Response Confirmation: Presence of Location header and confirmation body are asserted in several success scenarios (TC01, TC02 and others).
gaps: Schema / Business Validation: No explicit tests for well-formed XML that fails business/schema validation (e.g., missing required catalog fields, invalid versions, wrong element names) and asserting specific validation error messages.

Response Content-Type and Body Format: Tests do not assert the response Content-Type (text/plain vs application/json) or the exact response body format/schema — story notes "string" and implicit produces but tests only check for presence of a confirmation string/URI.
Success Content-Type for Requests: Successful scenarios do not explicitly assert that the request Content-Type is set to the required text/xml (or application/xml) for accepted uploads.

500 Internal Server Error / Server-side Failures: There is a test for backend unavailability (503) but not explicit simulation/assertion of 500 Internal Server Error (e.g., DB exception, unexpected server crash) and related recovery/notification behavior.
Atomicity / Transactional Rollback: No tests confirm the system does not leave partial state when processing fails mid-upload (e.g., partially applied catalog changes).
Deterministic Duplicate Behavior: TC25 leaves expected result open (201 or 409). There are no tests that assert a single expected behavior for duplicate-version submissions or the conflict semantics.
Rate-limiting / Throttling / Quotas: Standard rate-limiting and throttling scenarios are not covered (e.g., 429 responses under excessive requests), beyond general performance tests.
Precise Header Validation: No tests for header length limits, invalid characters in headers, or validation of optional header formats (e.g., max length of X-Killbill-Comment).
MIME Variants: No coverage for commonly accepted XML MIME types (application/xml, text/xml with charset variants) and differences in handling.
Response Header Consistency: Location header presence is asserted in some but not all successful tests — no test ensures Location is always present and correct across all success paths.
Observability / Auditing: No tests verify that createdBy/reason/comment are recorded in audit logs or persisted for later retrieval.

HTTP Status Determinism: Several tests allow multiple acceptable statuses (e.g., TC12, TC25) which reduces strictness of behavior verification; there are few tests asserting precise expected status codes for edge cases.
recommendations: Add schema-level validation tests: Create scenarios with well-formed XML that violates the catalog schema or business rules (missing mandatory elements, invalid types, out-of-range numbers) and assert specific validation errors (400 with detailed message or 422 if used).

Assert response Content-Type and body format: Add assertions that successful responses have the expected Content-Type (text/plain or application/json as per API contract) and validate the exact shape/content of the confirmation string/URI.

Explicitly set and assert request Content-Type: Ensure success test cases explicitly set Content-Type: text/xml (and application/xml variants) and add tests for charset mismatches to confirm server handling.
Simulate and assert 500 Internal Server Error: Add tests that simulate DB/serialization failures and assert 500 responses and that no partial catalog state is committed.
Transactional integrity tests: Introduce tests that cause a mid-processing failure and assert rollback (no partially created catalog entries) and meaningful error messages to clients.
Clarify and enforce duplicate-version behavior: Decide expected behavior (e.g., 409 Conflict or idempotent 201) and add strict tests asserting the chosen outcome and consistent response body.
Rate limiting/throttling tests: Add tests that exercise API rate limits and assert 429 responses or backoff behavior and that legitimate users are not incorrectly throttled under normal load.
Header validation tests: Add cases for overly long header values, illegal characters, and ensure optional headers are recorded or ignored per spec; assert audit/log persistence.

MIME variants and encoding tests: Add tests for application/xml, text/xml with charset, and explicit mismatches between declared charset and payload encoding to verify server rejection or correct handling.

Ensure Location header is always present: Add checks in all successful test cases that the Location header exists and contains the resource URL, and validate the returned URL points to a retrievable resource.

Make error expectations deterministic: Replace tests that allow multiple acceptable status codes with firm expectations where possible, or split into separate scenarios documenting each supported behavior.
Observability/audit tests: Verify that X-Killbill-CreatedBy/Reason/Comment are persisted in audit trails or resource metadata and exposed via GET/listing endpoints for the catalog.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/allCustomFields - Retrieve account customFields

covered: Valid Request: Multiple scenarios (TC01, TC02, TC05, TC08) verify successful retrieval with required and optional parameters.
Empty Response: TC06 and TC07 verify empty-array responses when no matching custom fields exist.
Query Parameters: Many scenarios cover valid and invalid query parameter combinations (objectType enums, audit enums, unexpected types, whitespace, XSS).
Audit handling: TC03, TC04, TC05, TC09 and regression TC21 validate FULL/MINIMAL/NONE audit behaviors and that audit isn't ignored.

Error handling: TC12 (400 invalid accountId), TC13 (404 not found), TC14/TC15 (401 auth failures), TC16/TC23 (503 service/dependency unavailable), TC19/TC20 (timeouts/retries/504 behavior) cover main error cases.
Security: TC17 (SQL injection) and TC18 (XSS) test common injection attacks and do not reveal sensitive info.
Performance/scale: TC11, TC25, TC26, TC30 cover large numbers, concurrency, and heavy-load behavior; TC11 includes a response-time expectation.
Edge cases & input validation: Many edge cases covered (TC29 single custom field, TC31 partial inputs, TC32/TC33/TC34/TC35/TC36 malformed/whitespace/empty/too long inputs).
Schema & contract: Several scenarios assert that each returned object matches the CustomField schema (TC01, TC02, TC05).

Integration & regression: TC22 (backward compatibility), TC23 (audit service dependency), TC24 (data consistency), TC21 (audit parameter regression), and TC39 (recovery) provide integration/regression coverage.
gaps: Pagination: No test coverage for pagination semantics (limit/offset/page tokens) or behavior if API should paginate very large result sets; TC11 asserts large dataset returned but does not verify pagination headers or semantics.
Rate limiting / Throttling: No scenarios exercise API rate limits (429 responses) or client behavior under throttling.
Caching Behavior: No tests validate caching headers or cache-related flows (ETag, If-None-Match, Cache-Control, Last-Modified, 304 responses).
Authorization granularity (403): Tests cover missing/invalid tokens (401) but there are no scenarios for insufficient permissions/authorization-specific failures returning 403.
Response headers / content-type: Tests do not explicitly assert Content-Type, Content-Length, or other response header correctness (except implicit checks); contract requires application/json.

Pagination/performance trade-offs: While performance under heavy load is addressed, there are no tests combining pagination with concurrency or verifying streaming/partial responses for very large payloads.
Cache invalidation: No scenarios for cache invalidation when custom fields are added/updated/deleted.
Precise schema failure cases: While schema conformance is asserted for success cases, there are no negative tests showing how malformed items are reported if the backend returns unexpected shapes.
recommendations: Add explicit pagination tests: if the API supports/should support pagination, add scenarios for page size, page tokens/offsets, boundary conditions (exactly page size, page size+1), and pagination response headers.
Add rate-limiting tests: simulate bursts to verify 429 responses, retry-after header handling, and client backoff behavior.
Add caching tests: verify ETag and Cache-Control headers, test If-None-Match/If-Modified-Since flows producing 304, and behavior when data changes (cache invalidation).
Add authorization role/permission tests: include scenarios for authenticated but unauthorized requests returning 403 and ensure RBAC rules are enforced.
Assert response headers explicitly: add checks for Content-Type: application/json, Content-Length sanity, and any required custom headers.
Add combined stress/pagination tests: verify system behavior when many concurrent clients request paginated data and validate performance and correctness.
Add negative schema tests: simulate backend anomalies (unexpected/missing fields) to confirm the API fails fast or sanitizes output and returns clear errors/logging.

Add cache/dependency-failure fallbacks: tests where audit or other dependent services return partial data or degraded responses (e.g., partial fields), to assert documented behavior and error messages.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: PUT /1.0/kb/bundles/{bundleId}/resume - Resume a bundle

covered: Valid Request: Multiple success scenarios (TC01-TC04, TC18) verify a paused bundle can be resumed immediately or scheduled (requestedDate) and with pluginProperty and optional headers.
Required Header Validation: TC01 and TC07 validate presence and absence of the required X-Killbill-CreatedBy header.
Path Parameter Validation: TC06 checks invalid bundleId format; TC05 covers non-existing bundle (404).
Success Response: TC01..TC04 assert the expected success status (204) and state transition (bundle -> active) and subscription resumption.
Query Parameters: requestedDate (future, scheduled) and pluginProperty (single/multiple/large count) are tested (TC02, TC03, TC13).
Error Scenarios: 400 for invalid state / invalid input (TC06, TC07, TC08, TC09, TC20, TC19) and 404 for missing resource (TC05) are explicitly covered.
Authorization: TC10 covers unauthorized access (401/403).
Concurrency & Idempotency: TC21 covers concurrent requests and expected responses for first/next callers; TC15 covers retry after transient failure.
Performance & Load: TC22 includes acceptable response time under normal/peak load.
System & Dependency Failures: TC14 (service unavailable -> 500) and TC25 (plugin degraded -> 504 or 204) are present.
Security: TC16 and TC17 cover SQL injection and XSS attempt handling in inputs.

Edge cases & robustness: TC11 (extra params), TC12 (max header lengths), TC24 (legacy header formats), TC26 (whitespace/case variations), TC23 (regression) cover many robustness/regression/back-compat scenarios.
gaps: Produces / Content-Type: The story notes "Produces: application/json" but there are no assertions verifying response Content-Type headers (including for 204 responses) or body presence/absence.

Invalid requestedDate formats and parsing errors: Tests cover future requestedDate (TC02) and past date rejection (TC20) but do not cover malformed date strings (e.g., "not-a-date") or time-zone / “today” boundary conditions.

PluginProperty transmission formats: The suite checks array, non-array and large counts (TC03, TC19, TC13) but lacks explicit tests for alternative encodings (repeated query params vs. comma separated vs. URL-encoded values) and how the server maps those to the pluginProperty array.

Partial / unexpected transitional states: The story mentions "invalid state" generically; tests cover active and cancelled (TC08/TC09) but do not exercise other possible states or transitional states (e.g., PENDING, SUSPENDED, or mid-transaction states) that may affect resume behavior.
Response body / error payload shape: Error scenarios assert status codes but do not assert the structure/fields of error responses (consistent error codes/messages/JSON schema).

Idempotency semantics: Concurrency test (TC21) covers first vs subsequent responses but does not explicitly assert idempotency guarantees or the API's documented behavior on repeat identical requests.
Rate limiting & throttling: No tests cover rate limiting behavior or API throttling under burst traffic (relevant in guidelines).
Caching behavior: While not usually applicable to PUT, there are no tests asserting appropriate cache-related headers or that caching layers do not cache non-idempotent requests (per guidelines).
recommendations: Add Content-Type and response-body assertions: verify response headers (Content-Type: application/json) for error responses and confirm 204 responses do not contain a body or include expected headers.

Add malformed requestedDate tests: include invalid-date-format (e.g., "abc"), timezone boundary tests (requestedDate == today at different timezones), and business-rule tests for "today" vs "immediate".

Expand pluginProperty format tests: include repeated query param form (pluginProperty=prop1=val1&pluginProperty=prop2=val2), URL-encoded values, comma-separated and empty-value cases, and validate how they map into server-side pluginProperty arrays.

Exercise transitional and additional bundle states: add scenarios for other lifecycle states (e.g., PENDING, SUSPENDED, pending-cancellation) to ensure resume rejection or acceptance is correct and consistent with business rules.
Assert error payload schema: add tests that validate JSON error response structure (errorCode, message, field, etc.) and localization/consistent messaging.

Idempotency tests: include explicit idempotency tests (repeat identical request multiple times) to document and verify server behavior (should be safe/repeatable or return a deterministic error/status).
Rate limiting and throttling: add stress/burst tests that assert correct 429 responses or backoff behavior under high request rates.

Security/input encoding fuzzing: expand security tests to include URL-encoded payloads, header-encoded attacks, and ensure pluginProperty and headers are sanitized and stored safely; include checks on audit log escaping.
Integration/contract tests: add an API contract test that ensures the OpenAPI/Swagger contract (if present) is satisfied (parameter types, required headers, produced media types).

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: POST /1.0/kb/accounts/payments - Trigger a payment using the account external key

covered: Valid Payload: Multiple success scenarios cover creation with required params, optional params, combinations (paymentMethodId, controlPluginName, pluginProperty) and header use (X-Killbill-CreatedBy, Reason, Comment).
Response Validation: Success scenarios assert 201, response body is a Payment object and Location header presence.
Required Fields: Tests cover required query param externalKey and required header X-Killbill-CreatedBy, and malformed/missing request-body handling (400).

Error Cases: Acceptance error scenarios from the story are covered — 404 (account not found), 400 (malformed body / missing params / invalid paymentMethodId), 401 (unauthorized), 402 (declined), 422 (aborted by plugin), 502 (gateway submission failure), 503 (unknown status), 504 (timeout).
Plugin Behavior: Control plugin abort and plugin property handling are explicitly tested, including a regression scenario.
Boundary Tests: Large payload, minimal values, partial input and empty-database cases are present.
Security: Malicious payload (injection) test is included.
Integration & Resilience: Dependent-service unavailable test and gateway failure scenarios are present.
Performance & Non-functional: Performance/throughput/response-time and resource utilization tests are included (normal, peak, stress).
Backward Compatibility & Regression: Tests to verify backward-compatible payloads and a previous bug with pluginProperty are included.
Accessibility/Docs: Documentation & error message clarity check is present.
gaps: Duplicate Submission / Idempotency: No test verifies handling of duplicate POSTs (same payload submitted twice) or idempotency keys.
Internal Server Error (500) Simulation: No explicit test simulates server-side failures such as DB write failure or unhandled exceptions that should produce a 500.

Deep Schema / Field-level Validation: While malformed JSON is tested, there are no focused tests for field-level validation (e.g., amount ranges, negative amounts, currency format/unsupported currency, transactionType invalid values, excessive precision).

Payment Schema Assertions: Tests assert a "valid Payment object" but do not enumerate/validate required Payment fields, types, or relationships (e.g., transaction IDs, status values, timestamps, currency consistency).

Control Plugin / PluginProperty Edge Cases: No tests for array parsing edge-cases (single value vs comma-separated vs repeated parameters), URL-encoding of plugin properties, or invalid plugin property formats.
Header Edge Cases: No tests for header edge cases (empty X-Killbill-CreatedBy, excessively long header values, or malformed header values) or for X-Killbill-Reason/Comment variations.
Location Header Validation: Presence of Location is tested but not the correctness/format of the URL (resource id, canonical path) or Content-Type header verification.
Concurrency / Race Conditions: No tests for race conditions (e.g., concurrent payments against same account/payment method, or payment while account is being modified/deleted).
Duplicate/Idempotent Payment Prevention: No tests to ensure the system prevents accidental duplicate charges (replay protection), e.g., idempotency token behavior if supported.
Rate Limiting / Throttling: Performance tests exist but there are no explicit rate-limiting or throttling tests (how the API responds when client exceeds allowed rate).
403 Forbidden: Authorization tests cover 401 but not 403 (authenticated but insufficient privileges).

Server-side caching / headers: Although primarily a POST endpoint, there is no check that responses include appropriate cache-control/no-cache headers or other relevant response headers after mutation.
recommendations: Add duplicate-submission tests: submit identical requests twice (with and without idempotency keys) and assert behavior (either deduplication with 200/201 idempotent response or rejection) to prevent double-charging.
Simulate internal failures: add tests that mock DB or service-layer failures to assert a 500 Internal Server Error and useful error payload/logging.

Add field-level validation tests: test negative/zero amounts, out-of-range values, invalid currency codes, invalid transactionType values, too-large numeric precision, and assert 400 with clear validation errors.

Enumerate Payment schema assertions: extend success checks to validate key Payment fields (paymentId, transactionId, amount, currency, transactionType, status, createdBy, timestamps) and their formats/types.
Plugin parameter edge-case tests: cover controlPluginName as repeated query parameter, as array, with whitespace, and pluginProperty with URL-encoded characters, duplicate keys, and invalid formats.

Header robustness tests: validate behavior when X-Killbill-CreatedBy is empty, extremely long, or contains special characters; verify optional headers (Reason, Comment) accept/limit lengths and characters.
Location and response headers: assert Location URL format (contains payment id and correct path), Content-Type is application/json, and appropriate no-cache headers for POST responses.

Concurrency tests: add tests that perform concurrent payment requests against the same account/payment method to catch race conditions and consistency issues (also verify atomicity and correct final balances/status).
Rate limiting: include tests that exceed expected rate limits to verify 429 or documented throttling behavior and that clients receive appropriate Retry-After headers.
Authorization matrix: add tests for authenticated-but-forbidden (403) responses when a principal lacks permissions, and test role-based access if applicable.
Add explicit server error and retry behavior tests for dependent services (DB, queue, gateway) to confirm documented retry/backoff behavior and error codes.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: DELETE /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/emails/{email} - Delete email from account

covered: Valid Deletion: Multiple scenarios (TC01, TC02, TC12, TC13, TC17, TC18) validate successful 204 deletions with required and optional headers.
Error Handling - Non-Existent Resource: TC03, TC04, TC09 cover 404 responses when account or email is not found.
Validation Errors (400): TC05 and TC06 verify invalid accountId and invalid email formats produce 400.
Required Header Validation: TC07 checks missing required header (X-Killbill-CreatedBy) handling.
Optional Headers: TC02 verifies optional headers (X-Killbill-Reason, X-Killbill-Comment) are accepted.
Authorization: TC10 tests invalid/expired token producing 401.
Dependency / Service Failure: TC11 simulates downstream/unavailable service producing 503.
Concurrency and Race Conditions: TC15 covers concurrent delete behavior and expected mixed responses.
Security / Input Sanitization: TC16 checks injection/XSS in the email parameter results in validation error.
Performance: TC14 asserts response time threshold.
Regression & Compatibility: TC17 and TC18 cover previously fixed bugs and legacy client behavior.
Resilience / Retry: TC19 verifies retry after transient network failure results in success.
gaps: Soft-delete semantics / auditability: No tests verify whether deletion is soft (marked deleted) vs hard delete, or whether deleted emails are recoverable/visible to admin or audit logs.

Response body / produced media type checks: The story specifies produces application/json but DELETE returns 204. There are no explicit assertions that the response body is empty or that appropriate Content-Type/Content-Length headers are present/absent for 204 responses.

Idempotency semantics not clearly tested: Beyond TC15 concurrent scenario expecting 404 for subsequent requests, there is no explicit test for repeated sequential DELETE calls (should subsequent calls return 404 or be idempotent 204?). The acceptance criteria suggests 404 for not-found but this conflict should be asserted/clarified.
URL encoding / special characters in path parameter: No tests for emails containing characters that require URL-encoding (e.g., +, %20, slash) to ensure correct path-handling and routing.
403 / insufficient privileges: There is an authorization negative test (401) but no test for authenticated users without sufficient privileges (403) if the API has role-based access.
Server 500 / unexpected server error: TC11 covers 503, but there is no test that simulates a generic internal server error (500) or database failure leading to 500.
Rate limiting and throttling: No tests for rate limiting, abuse protection or how bursts of requests are handled beyond concurrency count in TC15.
Header validation beyond presence: No tests validate constraints on header values (length, accepted characters for X-Killbill-CreatedBy) or behavior when optional headers are malformed.
Cache-related headers and behavior: No checks for caching (ETag, Cache-Control) or whether responses include appropriate cache controls even if less relevant for DELETE.

Multiple identical/duplicate emails and uniqueness: No tests check behavior when account contains duplicate email entries or when email addresses are linked to other resources (impact of referential integrity).
recommendations: Add a soft-delete / audit test: Verify whether deletion marks the email as deleted (soft delete) and that audit/entry is recorded, or assert that deletion is permanent depending on spec.

Assert response headers and body for 204: Add explicit checks that 204 responses have no body and that Content-Type/Content-Length behave as expected (and that produced application/json is respected where applicable).
Clarify and test idempotency: Add sequential repeat-delete tests to assert expected behavior (e.g., second delete returns 404 or 204) and make acceptance criteria explicit.
Test URL-encoding and special characters: Add cases for emails containing +, spaces (encoded), slashes or percent-encoded characters to ensure path param handling and routing is correct.
Add authorization/permission tests: Include a 403 scenario for authenticated users lacking permission or role, if RBAC applies.
Simulate generic server errors (500): Add tests to simulate DB constraint violations / unexpected exceptions to ensure appropriate 5xx responses and error messaging.
Add rate-limiting / throttling tests: Verify API behavior under rapid-burst requests (beyond concurrency) and proper 429 or throttling responses if applicable.
Validate header formats and limits: Add tests for invalid/malformed values in X-Killbill-CreatedBy and optional headers to ensure header validation is enforced and documented.
Test email uniqueness and effects on related resources: Add tests for accounts with duplicates or emails that are referenced elsewhere to validate deletion behavior and error handling.
If caching is relevant in your platform, add tests for cache-control/ETag headers or ensure DELETE invalidates caches where applicable.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: DELETE /1.0/kb/admin/healthcheck - Put the host out of rotation

covered: Valid Deletion: TC01 verifies successful DELETE returns 204 and host is marked out of rotation.
Authorization: TC02 and TC03 cover missing and invalid authentication (401).
Error Handling: TC05 and TC06 cover service-unavailable (503) and internal server error (500) responses.
Non-Existent / Already-Out Cases: TC04 and TC14 cover attempts to take a host out of rotation when it is already out or when no hosts exist (conflict semantics).
Invalid Method Handling: TC07 tests method-not-allowed (405).
Input Validation / Security: TC09 and TC13 cover malicious request body and header injection attempts.
Concurrency and Performance: TC10 and TC11 include response-time expectations and concurrent DELETE handling (race conditions).
Regression / Correctness: TC12 validates that the host state is actually updated and can be queried afterward.
Extra Parameters: TC08 verifies that extra query parameters do not break the operation.
gaps: Produces / Content-Type header: No assertions that responses include the declared application/json Content-Type header (the story specifies "Produces: application/json").

Soft-delete semantics and persistence model: No tests check whether the host is soft-deleted (flagged) versus hard-removed, or verify persistent state beyond an API-level flag (DB/state verification beyond "marked out of rotation").
Role-based authorization / Forbidden (403): Tests cover unauthenticated (401) and invalid tokens, but not an authenticated user lacking admin privileges (403).

Explicit idempotency behavior: Repeated DELETE behavior is only partially covered (TC11/TC04 imply conflicts). The spec does not define whether repeated deletes should be idempotent (204) or return 409; tests assume 409 but the API spec is ambiguous.
Content negotiation and headers: No tests for response headers such as Cache-Control, ETag, or other operational headers; also no assertion of response Content-Length behavior for 204.
Rate limiting and throttling: No tests for rate limits or API throttling beyond simple concurrency/performance timing.
Audit/logging and observability: No tests to verify that the operation is logged/audited or that healthcheck/out-of-rotation events emit metrics.
recommendations: Add explicit tests that verify the response Content-Type header is application/json where applicable, and assert header semantics for 204 responses (e.g., absence/presence of Content-Length).

Clarify and test idempotency semantics: decide whether repeated DELETE should return 204 (idempotent success) or 409 and update tests accordingly; add a dedicated idempotency test (repeat same DELETE twice from same client).
Add role-based authorization tests: include an authenticated non-admin user and assert 403 Forbidden if appropriate.
Add persistence-level checks for soft-delete vs hard-delete: verify DB/state flag or long-term status (not only API-level flag) to ensure correct persistence semantics.
Introduce rate-limiting tests: simulate rapid-fire requests to confirm proper throttling and expected 429 responses if rate limits apply.
Add audit/logging/metrics tests or hooks: verify that actions are recorded in audit logs or emit expected metrics/events.

Clarify expected behavior for request bodies on DELETE and align tests: either accept and ignore bodies (return 204) or reject non-empty bodies (return 400); update TC09 to match the defined behavior.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/catalog/availableBasePlans - Retrieve available base plans

covered: Valid Request: TC01 and TC02 cover successful retrieval (with and without accountId) and check 200 + application/json + response body.
Empty Response: TC03 and TC14 verify behavior when the catalog is empty and ensure empty JSON array with 200.
Query Parameters: TC02, TC04, TC05 and TC08 exercise accountId valid, non-existent, invalid-format, and unsupported extra parameters.
Authorization: TC06 covers unauthenticated/invalid-token cases returning 401.
Error Handling / Service Failures: TC07 (503), TC17 (504 timeout) and TC16 (dependent service degraded/partial data) cover downstream failures and partial responses.
Security Validation: TC12 and TC13 address SQL injection and XSS attempts on accountId and expect validation errors without leakage.
Performance / Scalability: TC09, TC10 and TC11 cover normal load, concurrent requests, and very large payload handling.
Backward compatibility & Regression: TC15 and TC14 explicitly check compatibility and a previously fixed empty-array bug.
Accessibility / Machine-readability: TC18 ensures valid JSON and that responses are machine-readable.
gaps: Pagination: No scenarios validate pagination behavior (page/limit/offset), page boundaries, or server-side defaults for large result sets.
Caching Behavior / Conditional GET: No tests for ETag, Last-Modified, Cache-Control headers or conditional requests (If-None-Match / 304 Not Modified).
Rate Limiting / Throttling: No tests for API rate limits (429) or behavior under abusive request rates.
Authorization nuances (403): Missing tests for authenticated but unauthorized clients (403 Forbidden) / role-based access differences.

PlanDetail Schema Validation: Tests assert "required fields" generically but there are no explicit schema-level tests for each PlanDetail field type, presence, allowed values, or malformed PlanDetail objects.

Tenant-specific catalog behavior: Background references tenant-specific catalogs but there are no explicit scenarios exercising tenant-scoped catalogs vs global catalogs and their interactions with accountId.
Conditional / Partial Responses: While TC16 mentions partial content (206) as possible, there is no concrete test verifying 206 behavior and headers for partial responses.
Content negotiation and Accept header handling: No tests for Accept header variations (e.g., explicit non-JSON Accept leading to 406) or charset handling.
Response size / streaming edge-cases: Large payload TC11 asserts "no truncation" but there are no tests for chunked/streamed responses, memory limits, or client-side timeouts beyond TC17.
Error message content & internationalization: Tests check that error messages exist but do not verify consistent error codes, error structure, or i18n/localization behavior.
recommendations: Add pagination tests: cover page/limit/offset query params, default paging, out-of-range pages, and large page sizes to ensure predictable behavior and performance.
Add caching/conditional GET tests: verify ETag and Cache-Control headers, support for If-None-Match returning 304, and correct cache expiry semantics.
Add rate-limiting tests: simulate high-frequency requests to validate throttling behavior and proper 429 responses with Retry-After headers.
Add authorization nuance tests: include scenarios for authenticated-but-forbidden users (403), role-based access restrictions, and tenant isolation tests to verify tenant-specific catalog behavior.
Add PlanDetail schema tests: validate each required field, data types, value ranges, optional vs required fields, and contract tests against the PlanDetail definition.
Add concrete partial-content tests: if 206 is supported, create tests that produce and validate partial responses and appropriate headers; otherwise assert 200 with clear error messaging.
Add content-negotiation tests: verify Accept header handling (application/json vs unsupported types) and correct 406/200 behavior.
Add streaming / large-response robustness tests: verify client and server behavior for very large responses (memory, chunking, connection drops) and ensure no truncation.
Add error structure and message consistency tests: validate error payload schema, non-leakage of internal details, and consistent localization handling if applicable.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: DELETE /1.0/kb/bundles/{bundleId}/customFields - Remove custom fields from bundle

covered: Valid Deletion: multiple scenarios (TC01-TC05, TC18) verify successful deletions (all, single, multiple) and expected HTTP 204 responses.
Non-Existent Resource: TC07 and TC23 cover 404 behavior when the bundle does not exist or DB is empty.
Input Validation: bundleId UUID format checks (TC06, TC22), customField UUID format and empty value checks (TC09, TC19) are present.
Authorization / Authentication: invalid/expired token is tested (TC13) and missing required header X-Killbill-CreatedBy is tested (TC08).
Optional Headers: usage of X-Killbill-Reason and X-Killbill-Comment tested (TC04) and comment length edge cases tested (TC20, TC21).
Idempotency & Non-present Items: TC10 verifies deleting a non-present custom field results in 204 and does not remove other fields (idempotent behavior).
Concurrency and Race Conditions: TC16 tests concurrent delete requests for the same bundle.
Performance / Scale: TC15 tests removal performance with a large number of custom fields.
Integration / Degraded Dependencies: TC12 and TC24 cover service unavailability and degraded dependent storage behavior (503/504).
Security / Injection: header injection attempt is covered (TC14).
Regression & Data Consistency: TC17 and TC25 verify removal does not affect other bundles and DB consistency after deletion.
Extra/Unsupported Params: TC11 verifies extra query params are ignored.
gaps: Soft-delete semantics: no test verifies whether deletion is a soft delete (flagging) vs hard delete or checks deleted-flag visibility in DB.
Authorization granularity: missing tests for authorization failures with valid auth but insufficient permissions (403 Forbidden) or role-based access controls.
Mixed parameter validation: no test for mixed valid and invalid customField UUIDs in the same request (e.g., one valid UUID + one malformed UUID).
Server error handling (500): no explicit scenario simulates unexpected server-side failures (e.g., DB exception) returning 500 Internal Server Error.
Rate limiting / Throttling: guidelines mention rate limiting but there are no tests for high request rates or throttling behaviour.
Response headers / contract: no checks for response headers (Content-Type, application/json when applicable, caching headers, ETag) or auditing headers.

CreatedBy/Reason/Comment validation beyond length: no tests for invalid characters, maximum length enforcement for X-Killbill-CreatedBy or X-Killbill-Reason, or missing optional headers combined with other errors.
Edge case of many repeated query params: not covered (e.g., extremely many customField params or limit exhaustion).
Soft/Hard delete reconciliation and recovery: no tests verifying restore/replay or how deleted state is exposed to downstream systems.
recommendations: Add soft-delete vs hard-delete tests: verify whether records are flagged as deleted in the DB (deleted_at, is_deleted) and whether deleted metadata is accessible or permanently removed depending on product expectation.
Add authorization tests for insufficient privileges: include scenarios where authentication succeeds but user lacks permission (expect 403 Forbidden) to cover RBAC/security policies.

Add mixed customField parameter validation: test requests containing both valid and invalid customField UUIDs and assert the API responds consistently (reject whole request vs ignore malformed entries) according to spec.
Simulate server-side failures: add tests that force DB exceptions or unhandled errors to ensure the API returns 500 and an appropriate error payload.
Add rate limiting / throttling tests: verify behavior under burst traffic and assert correct status codes/Retry-After headers if applicable.

Assert response headers and content-type: add assertions for Content-Type, any audit headers, and (if applicable) caching-related headers even for DELETE responses to ensure API contract completeness.

Validate header constraints: add tests for CreatedBy/Reason/Comment field validation beyond length (illegal characters, extremely long strings for CreatedBy/Reason, and missing optional headers combined with other invalid inputs).
Test extreme query param counts and limits: include scenarios with many customField parameters to validate request parsing and any server limits.
Add explicit idempotency sequence test: call DELETE twice sequentially and assert the second call’s expected status (204 or another documented response) to make idempotency explicit.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/credits/{creditId} - Retrieve a credit by id

covered: Valid Request: TC01 and TC02 validate successful retrieval for both CREDIT_ADJ and CBA_ADJ types and check status 200, Content-Type, and id/type matching.
Empty / Not Found responses: TC03, TC04 and TC18 cover cases where no matching credit exists and expect 404 with an error message.
Input validation: TC05, TC14, TC16, TC17 cover invalid UUID formats, truncated/whitespace cases and syntactic boundary conditions returning 400/404 as appropriate.
Authorization (basic): TC06 and TC07 cover missing and expired/invalid token cases (401).
Query parameter handling: TC08 verifies extra/unexpected query parameters are ignored and do not break the endpoint.
Error handling for downstream failure: TC10 covers database unavailability and expects 503.
Type-filtering: TC11 ensures that InvoiceItem entries that are not CREDIT_ADJ or CBA_ADJ are treated as not-found (404).
Security: TC12 and TC13 test for SQL injection and XSS attempts in the creditId path parameter.
Performance & concurrency: TC09 and TC19 address acceptable response time under load and a concurrent-request scenario.
Regression and backward compatibility: TC15 and TC20 provide regression and backward-compatibility checks.
gaps: Pagination: No scenarios test pagination or large-result-set behavior (limit/offset, page tokens) — important if the endpoint ever lists/filter returns multiple items.
Caching behavior / conditional requests: No tests for caching headers (ETag, Cache-Control, Last-Modified) or conditional GETs (If-None-Match/If-Modified-Since => 304).
Rate limiting / throttling semantics: No tests for rate limits / server behavior under intensive request bursts that may produce 429 responses or backoff behavior.
Authorization nuances: Tests cover 401 but not 403/role-based access control or scopes (forbidden vs unauthorized differences).

Response schema field-level validation: Tests assert that the response is a valid InvoiceItem object but do not enumerate/validate required fields, types, formats (dates, amounts, currency, invoiceId, timestamps, etc.).
Content negotiation: No tests for Accept header variations (e.g., unsupported media types yielding 406) or explicit checks for consistent Content-Type for different Accept values.
Header validation: Beyond Content-Type, headers like Cache-Control, ETag, Retry-After (on 503/429), and standard security headers are not validated.
Rate-limit / 429 expectations: Concurrent/performance tests expect 200 for all; they do not assert or handle the case where the system enforces rate limiting and returns 429.
Edge-case data volume tests: No tests for very large payloads in responses (very large InvoiceItem lists or very large field values), or response streaming behavior.
Negative tests for malformed requests beyond UUID path param (e.g., malformed URL encoding, invalid characters) are limited to a few security cases.
recommendations: Add pagination tests: create/seed many InvoiceItem credits and verify limit/offset or page token parameters when listing (if applicable), and behavior when page > last page.
Add caching / conditional GET tests: verify ETag and Cache-Control headers are present, and that If-None-Match / If-Modified-Since produce 304 when appropriate and 200 otherwise.
Add rate-limiting / throttling tests: hammer the endpoint to observe 429 behavior (or confirm absence) and check Retry-After headers where applicable.
Expand authorization tests: include 403 (forbidden) scenarios if there are role/scope restrictions and test token with insufficient privileges.
Tighten response schema validation: assert all required InvoiceItem fields, their types and formats (e.g., id UUID format, amounts numeric, dates ISO-8601), not just id and type.
Add content-negotiation tests: requests with different Accept headers (e.g., application/xml, */*) and ensure correct content-type negotiation or 406 responses.
Validate response headers: add assertions for Cache-Control, ETag, Last-Modified, Retry-After (for 503/429), and common security headers (e.g., X-Content-Type-Options).
Clarify and test rate limiting expectations in performance/concurrency tests: define acceptable behavior (e.g., graceful degradation vs 429) and assert it.
Add tests for very large response payloads/field sizes to detect memory/time issues.
Include URL-encoding and path-edge cases: percent-encoded IDs, extremely long path segments, and unusual but legal characters to ensure robust parsing.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: POST /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/block - Block an account

covered: Valid Payload: Multiple successful creation scenarios (TC01–TC05, TC16–TC17) ensure resources are created with valid payloads.
Optional Parameters & Headers: Tests cover optional headers (X-Killbill-Reason, X-Killbill-Comment) and query parameters requestedDate and pluginProperty (TC02, TC03, TC04).
Invalid Payload / Malformed Body: Malformed JSON and missing body are tested (TC09, TC10).
Account Identifier Validation: Invalid accountId format and SQL injection attempt are tested (TC07, TC13).
Non-Existent Resource Handling: 404 for non-existent account is covered (TC06).
Required Header Validation: Missing required header X-Killbill-CreatedBy is tested (TC08).
Server Error Handling (downstream): DB unavailable and plugin unavailable simulated (TC12, TC22) producing 503 responses.
Duplicate/Regression: Regression for duplicate BlockingState entries is explicitly covered (TC23).
Large Payloads: Handling of large BlockingState payloads is covered (TC20).
Security: Malicious payload detection is covered (TC14).
Plugins / Integration: Plugin-triggered behavior and plugin-unavailable cases are covered (TC21, TC22).
Performance/Scale: High concurrency and resource utilization under sustained load are addressed (TC25, TC26).
Edge Cases: Empty pluginProperty, max/min field length edge cases are covered (TC15, TC16, TC17).
Authorization: Unauthorized (no token) scenario is covered (TC11).
Response Semantics: Success response code 201 and returned JSON array of BlockingState(s) is asserted in success scenarios (TC01, TC02, etc.).
gaps: Field-level Validation: No explicit tests for invalid values inside the BlockingState schema (e.g., missing required fields within the object, invalid enum values, string length validation error paths beyond happy-path storage).
Schema Conformance / Content-Type: No tests assert response Content-Type or validate full response schema (field presence/types) against the BlockingState definition.
Invalid Query Parameter Formats: No negative tests for invalid requestedDate format or invalid pluginProperty types (non-array, non-string entries).
Unsupported Media Type: No test for sending incorrect Content-Type (e.g., missing or non-application/json resulting in 415).

Idempotency / Duplicate Submission Behavior: TC23 checks duplicate-creation regression but there is no explicit test for repeated identical submissions (idempotency) and the expected semantic (e.g., 200/201/409) is not asserted.
Role-based Authorization / Forbidden (403): Tests include 401 for missing auth, but not 403 cases for authenticated users lacking permissions/roles.
Generic 500 Server Errors: Only 503 scenarios are present; there is no test for generic 500 Internal Server Error handling and client-visible error shape.
Rate Limiting / Throttling: No tests exercise rate limiting or throttling behavior under burst traffic (distinct from performance under concurrency).
Response Headers & Location: No assertions for important response headers (e.g., Location, ETag) or other operational headers.
Pagination / GET-related behavior: Not applicable to this POST endpoint but present in guidelines—no tests (acceptable), included here for completeness.
recommendations: Add negative tests that validate the BlockingState schema: missing required fields in body, invalid enum values, numeric/date field validation — assert 400 with meaningful error messages.
Add tests to validate response Content-Type and full response schema conformance (field names, types, and presence) against the BlockingState definition.
Add negative tests for query parameters: invalid requestedDate formats, pluginProperty with wrong types, excessively long pluginProperty values to ensure robust validation and 400 responses.
Add a test for unsupported media type (Content-Type != application/json) expecting 415.
Add idempotency/duplicate-submission scenarios: re-send the same request and assert the expected behavior (no duplicates, appropriate status code like 201 vs 200 vs 409 as per API contract).
Add role/permission tests to cover 403 Forbidden responses for authenticated users lacking permission to block accounts.
Include a generic 500 error simulation test to ensure the service returns consistent error structure for unexpected server failures.
Add rate-limiting/throttling tests (burst requests from same client) to validate 429 or throttling behavior if applicable.
Assert important operational/diagnostic response headers when relevant (e.g., Location for created resources, Content-Type, caching headers if any).
Where relevant, add explicit assertions about id formats and enforce/verify the UUID pattern per path parameter definition; include tests for borderline-but-valid UUIDs if needed.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/auditLogsWithHistory - Retrieve account audit logs with history by account id

covered: Valid Request: TC01, TC09, TC12 verify successful retrieval and full-history responses (200).
Empty Response: TC02 verifies behavior when no audit logs exist (empty JSON array).
Response format and schema presence: TC01 and TC12 check Content-Type and presence of required AuditLog fields.
Error responses: TC03 (404 for not found) and TC07 (500 internal error) cover server- and resource-level error handling.
Authorization (authentication) checks: TC05 and TC06 cover missing and invalid/expired tokens (401 responses).
Input validation and edge cases: TC04 (invalid format), TC17 (partial id), TC14 (whitespace), TC15 (case sensitivity), TC16 (max-length UUID) test input validation and edge behaviors.
Security: TC10 addresses SQL injection attempts and ensures no sensitive info is leaked.
Unsupported query parameters: TC08 verifies that unsupported params are ignored and do not break the endpoint.
Performance & concurrency: TC09 (large dataset) and TC11 (100 concurrent requests) cover performance and concurrency behavior in broad terms.
Dependency failure handling: TC13 covers degraded dependency behavior and possible 503 outcomes.
gaps: Pagination: No scenarios validate pagination (limit/offset/page tokens), partial retrieval, or correctness of paging metadata for large result sets.
Caching Behavior: No tests for caching headers (ETag, Last-Modified, Cache-Control) or conditional requests (If-None-Match / 304 responses).
Rate Limiting / Throttling: No explicit tests that cause and verify 429 responses or backoff behavior under sustained high request rates; TC11 covers concurrency but not rate limit behavior.
Authorization - Authorization scopes/roles/403: Tests cover authentication (401) but not authorization cases (403) where credentials are valid but lack required permissions/roles.

Query Parameters - Positive functional params: Only unsupported params are tested; there are no tests for any supported/optional query parameters or combinations (filters/sorts) if the API supports them.
Schema/Field-level validation: Tests assert "required fields exist" but do not validate field data types, formats (e.g., timestamps, enum values), or nested object correctness in detail.
Response headers and metadata: Apart from Content-Type in TC01, headers such as pagination links, request IDs, or caching headers are not validated.
Precise performance SLAs: TC09 and TC11 check performance conceptually but lack concrete SLA/threshold assertions and load-profile variations (ramp-up, sustained load).
recommendations: Add pagination tests: cover typical paging parameters (limit/offset or page token), boundary conditions (page sizes 1, max allowed), and correctness of paging metadata and ordering.
Add caching and conditional request tests: verify ETag/Last-Modified presence, exercise If-None-Match / If-Modified-Since to expect 304, and validate Cache-Control headers.
Add explicit rate-limiting tests: generate request bursts to trigger 429 responses and verify Retry-After headers and graceful degradation.
Add authorization role/permission tests: validate 403 behavior when authenticated users lack sufficient permissions and test multi-tenant isolation if applicable.
Add detailed schema validation tests: assert field types, timestamp formats, enum values, and nested object structures for AuditLog objects (not just presence).
Add header and telemetry checks: validate presence and format of request-id/correlation-id, Content-Length, and any pagination-related headers.
Make performance tests more measurable: define SLAs (e.g., p95 < X ms) and include load tests with ramp-up, sustained load, and teardown to detect resource leaks.
Add negative/robustness tests for malformed URL encoding, very long path segments, and unusual unicode characters in accountId, and verify no sensitive info is leaked in error responses.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/customFields - Retrieve account custom fields

covered: Valid Request: Multiple scenarios (TC01, TC02, TC03, TC16) verify successful retrieval for valid accountId and audit parameter variants.
Empty Response: TC04 and TC05 verify responses when an account has no custom fields and when an account does not exist (empty JSON array).
Query Parameters: Audit enum handling covered (FULL, MINIMAL, NONE in TC01/TC02/TC03/TC19) and invalid audit value handled (TC07). Extra/unsupported query params are tested (TC10).
Authorization: Missing and invalid auth tokens are tested (TC08, TC09) resulting in 401 responses.
Error handling / Input validation: Invalid accountId format and injection/XSS attempts are tested (TC06, TC13, TC14) to ensure 400 responses for malformed path params.
Robustness & integrations: Service unavailable and DB failure scenarios are covered (TC11, TC18).
Performance & concurrency: Large payload/performance (10,000 items) and concurrent requests are included (TC12, TC17).
Regression & compatibility & accessibility: Regression for audit param (TC19), backward compatibility (TC16), and JSON validity/accessibility (TC20) are present.
gaps: Pagination: No tests exercise pagination (limit/offset, page links) for large result sets; the spec/guidelines expect pagination checks.
Caching Behavior / Headers: No scenarios verify caching-related headers (ETag, Cache-Control, Last-Modified) or conditional requests (304).
Rate Limiting / Throttling: No explicit tests for rate limiting (429) or throttling behavior; TC17 covers concurrency but does not validate throttling or 429 semantics.
Authorization granularity: No tests for authorization-related 403 cases (forbidden/insufficient permissions) or role-based access.

Schema-level validation: While responses are checked as "JSON array of CustomField objects", there are no explicit tests validating the CustomField JSON schema (required fields, types, field-level constraints, media type application/json).

Ambiguity for non-existent account: TC05 asserts a 200 + empty array for non-existent accountId — the story does not explicitly define this behavior; this should be clarified and tested against the definitive API contract.
Response headers & content-type: No assertions about Content-Type, Content-Length, or other relevant response headers.
Edge-case performance and resource exhaustion: TC12 tests a single large dataset size; no tests for streaming, pagination under load, or memory usage limits.
recommendations: Add pagination tests: include scenarios that request paginated results (limit, offset/page) and validate correct slices, next/prev links, and total counts where applicable.
Add caching and conditional request tests: validate ETag, Cache-Control, Last-Modified headers and behavior for If-None-Match / If-Modified-Since (expect 304 when appropriate).
Add rate-limiting/throttling tests: simulate a high request rate and verify 429 responses or throttling behavior and related Retry-After headers.
Add schema validation tests: assert each CustomField object matches the API definition (required fields, types, allowed values) and that Content-Type is application/json.
Clarify and test semantics for non-existent accountId: decide whether the API should return 200 + empty array or 404; update TC05 accordingly and add tests for both behaviors depending on contract.
Add authorization/permission tests for 403 scenarios: verify access control rules (e.g., valid auth but insufficient permissions) and corresponding error codes/messages.
Add header assertions: verify Content-Type, CORS, Content-Length, and other operational headers in success and error responses.
Expand load/robustness testing: include streaming, varying large dataset sizes, and memory/latency boundary tests; validate graceful degradation and observability (logs/metrics) where possible.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: DELETE /1.0/kb/invoicePayments/{paymentId}/tags - Remove tags from payment

covered: Valid Deletion: Multiple success scenarios cover deleting all tags, single tag, multiple tags, and deletion when no tags exist (TC01-TC05, TC10).
Path parameter validation: Invalid format (non-UUID) and non-existent paymentId are tested (TC06, TC07).

Query parameters: Many variations covered — single tagDef, multiple tagDef, invalid tagDef format, injection attempt, extra unexpected parameter, large number of tagDefs (TC02, TC03, TC09, TC13, TC14, TC15).
Headers: Required header missing is tested; optional headers Reason and Comment are exercised; audit logging expectation is included (TC04, TC08, TC20).
Authorization: Unauthorized access scenario is present (TC11).
Error handling: Service unavailable and timeout scenarios covered (TC12, TC22).
Concurrency & Idempotency: Concurrent removal and repeated/no-op removal (tagDef not present) are covered (TC16, TC10).
Data consistency and regression: Post-removal consistency and regression checks present (TC21, TC18).
Performance: Load/performance check present (TC17).
Backward compatibility: Older client behaviour covered (TC19).
gaps: Produces / Content-Type verification: The story specifies "Produces: application/json" but there is no explicit check of Content-Type headers on success or error responses (even for empty 204 responses).
403 Forbidden / Authorization scope: There is a test for 401 unauthorized, but no scenario for authenticated but forbidden (403) or role/permission based access control.
500 Internal Server Error: There is a 503 / 504 coverage but no explicit test for generic 500 server errors (DB failure, unexpected exception) and how partial failures affect state.

Soft-delete semantics & audit state: If tags are soft-deleted, there are no tests asserting internal delete flags or recoverability; audit logging is checked but internal soft-delete behaviour is not validated (e.g., tag record retained but marked deleted).
Duplicate/ambiguous query params: No test for duplicate tagDef parameters (same ID repeated) or empty tagDef array/empty-value handling.
Malformed header values: No tests for invalid X-Killbill-CreatedBy/X-Killbill-Reason/X-Killbill-Comment formats or excessively long header values.
Rate limiting / throttling: Standard guidelines mention rate limiting; the suite has load/performance but not specific rate-limiting / throttling behavior tests.
Caching behaviour & headers: No tests for caching headers (ETag, Cache-Control) — even if less relevant for DELETE, API spec notes produces application/json and headers aren’t validated.
Transaction atomicity / partial failures: No test for partial failure scenarios where some tags fail to delete (e.g., DB constraint) and the final atomic state is validated.
recommendations: Add assertions for response headers (Content-Type) on both success and error responses to match "Produces: application/json" requirement, and verify empty-body 204 responses behave per spec.
Add a 403 Forbidden scenario to validate permission/role-based access control for authenticated but unauthorized users.
Introduce a test that simulates an internal server error (500) — e.g., mock a DB exception — and assert the system returns 500 and leaves data consistent or rolls back as required.
Add tests for soft-delete semantics if applicable: verify DB flags, ability to restore, and that audit entries reflect soft-deletion state.
Cover duplicate/ambiguous tagDef parameters and empty tagDef values (e.g., ?tagDef=&tagDef=uuid) to ensure deterministic handling.
Add negative tests for malformed or oversized header values (X-Killbill-CreatedBy, Reason, Comment) to ensure validation and proper error codes.
Add explicit rate-limiting / throttling tests (burst requests) to validate 429 responses or throttling behavior, separate from generic performance tests.
Add tests for transaction atomicity or partial failures: simulate partial DB failures to assert whether operation is atomic and the end state is correct.
Add checks for caching-related headers where applicable (ensure DELETE responses do not cause stale cache exposure) or explicitly assert presence/absence of caching headers as per API policy.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/block - Retrieve blocking states for account

covered: Valid Request: Multiple successful retrieval scenarios (no filters, filters, combinations) verify expected 200 responses and content.
Empty Response: Scenarios for account-with-no-blocking-states, non-existent account and empty database check empty-array behavior.
Query Parameters: Many combinations tested — blockingStateTypes, blockingStateSvcs, audit (FULL/MINIMAL/NONE), extra/unsupported params, partial inputs and multi-service filtering (regression case).
Authorization: Missing and invalid authentication token cases covered (401).
Error Handling: Invalid accountId and invalid query parameter values (blockingStateTypes, audit) covered with 400 expectations.
Service/Dependency Errors: Service unavailable/dependency failure and dependent-service-unavailable scenarios covered (503).
Performance/Scale: Large data volume and timeout/degraded performance scenarios present.
Security: Injection attack scenario checks input validation and non-compromise.
Concurrency/Integration: Concurrent requests, data consistency and regression for multi-value filtering are included.
Response Schema: Tests assert that returned items are JSON arrays and that BlockingState objects contain required fields (schema presence asserted).
gaps: Pagination: No tests for pagination parameters or verifying pagination behavior (limit/offset/page, or how data is chunked).
Caching Behavior: No assertions for response headers like Content-Type, ETag, Cache-Control, Last-Modified or caching semantics.
Rate Limiting/Throttling: No tests to exercise rate limits (429) or behavior under a large burst of requests beyond normal concurrency tests.
Authorization: 403/authorization scopes/role-based access control is not covered (only 401 covered).
Content Negotiation & Headers: Acceptance of application/json, Content-Type header, and other relevant response headers are not explicitly verified.
Multi-value blockingStateTypes: Regression covers multiple services but there is no explicit test for multiple blockingStateTypes values being supplied/handled.
Pagination-related performance: Large-data test checks volume but not pagination performance or streaming responses.
Explicit contract tests: No explicit contract/strict schema validation tests for field types, required vs optional fields, or negative schema tests (malformed object content).
HTTP semantics: No tests for idempotency headers, caching revalidation using ETag/If-None-Match, or conditional requests.
recommendations: Add pagination tests: include scenarios that pass paging parameters (if API supports them) or verify that the API explicitly documents absence of pagination; test correctness and completeness across pages and behaviour with large datasets.
Add caching/header tests: verify Content-Type = application/json, Cache-Control, ETag, Last-Modified and behavior for conditional requests (304 Not Modified) where applicable.
Add rate-limiting tests: simulate bursts to ensure 429 responses or throttling behavior and verify retry-after headers.
Add authorization/authorization-scope tests: include 403 tests for authenticated but unauthorized access and role-based access control scenarios.
Add strict schema/contract tests: validate field types, required fields, and negative cases where returned objects are malformed or missing required attributes.
Add multi-value filtering tests for blockingStateTypes: ensure multiple type values (e.g., &blockingStateTypes=SUBSCRIPTION&blockingStateTypes=ACCOUNT) are handled correctly.
Verify response headers and content negotiation: explicitly assert Content-Type and any API versioning headers, and backward-compatibility payload shape differences for legacy clients.
Expand concurrency/performance tests: include rate-limited concurrency tests and measure tail latency and resource usage; add pagination performance tests if relevant.
Clarify expected error codes for invalid inputs: add tests that assert whether API returns 400 vs 422 for specific invalid inputs and standardize behavior in tests.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/emails/{accountEmailId}/auditLogsWithHistory - Retrieve account email audit logs with history by id

covered: Valid Request: TC01 exercises a successful retrieval and checks HTTP 200, Content-Type and presence of expected fields.
Empty Response: TC02 verifies behavior when no audit logs exist (returns an empty JSON array with 200).
Non-existent resource errors: TC03 and TC04 cover 404 responses for missing account and missing accountEmail respectively.
Path parameter validation: TC05 and TC06 check invalid UUID-format path parameters and expect 400 responses.
Authorization (unauthenticated/invalid token): TC07 and TC08 cover missing and invalid auth (401 Unauthorized).
Service availability and downstream failures: TC09 (503) and TC12 (504) cover service unavailable and gateway timeout scenarios.
Query parameter tolerance: TC10 verifies the API tolerates extra/unexpected query parameters.
Large dataset / performance: TC11 tests very large result sets and basic response-time expectation.
Security: TC13 and TC14 include SQL injection and XSS path-parameter attack vectors and expect proper validation errors.
Ordering/regression: TC15 covers audit log ordering (changeDate descending).
Schema/backwards compatibility: TC16 explicitly validates response schema against the AuditLog definition.
State variations: TC18 and TC19 cover empty and partially populated database states.
Accessibility/UI rendering (integration use-case): TC17 attempts to validate that API output can be rendered accessibly in the UI (useful for integration/regression).
gaps: Pagination: No tests exercise pagination (limit/offset, page size, or pagination headers) or validate behavior for paged responses. The large-result test checks raw size and timing but not paging mechanics.
Caching Behavior / Conditional Requests: No tests check caching headers (ETag, Cache-Control) or conditional GET behavior (If-None-Match => 304).
Rate Limiting / Throttling: No tests exercise repeated/rapid requests to verify rate-limit responses (e.g., 429) or backoff behavior.

Authorization nuance / Permissions (403): Tests cover 401 (unauthenticated) but there are no tests for authenticated-but-forbidden scenarios (403) where a user lacks rights to view that account/email.
Account-email association mismatch: No scenario where accountEmailId exists but is not associated with the provided accountId (should confirm correct 404/403 semantics).

Content negotiation / Accept header: No tests for Accept header variations (e.g., requesting application/xml or missing Accept header) or for proper Content-Type consistency beyond the happy-path JSON check.

Exact error payload structure and status-body contract: While error messages are asserted in many scenarios, there is limited verification of a consistent error schema (error codes, fields, machine-readable error structure).
Rate/Load stability beyond a single large-response check: TC11 tests >1000 items and a perf threshold, but there are no sustained load/throughput tests to validate stability under concurrent load.

URL encoding and edge-case path inputs: Although injection/XSS are tested, there is no explicit coverage for encoded characters, extremely long path params, or multi-segment anomalies that could affect routing.
recommendations: Add pagination tests: include limit/offset or page-based queries (if supported) and validate correct subsets, pagination metadata (links/total/count) and behavior for page boundaries.
Add caching and conditional GET tests: verify presence of Cache-Control/ETag headers on 200 responses, and test If-None-Match/If-Modified-Since flows expecting 304 where appropriate.
Add rate-limiting tests: simulate burst traffic and confirm proper 429 or other throttling responses and headers (Retry-After).
Add authorization-permission tests (403): create scenarios where the request is authenticated but the caller lacks permission to view the account/email and assert 403 and consistent error payload.
Add association-mismatch test: exercise the case where accountEmailId exists but is not linked to the specified accountId and assert the intended behavior (likely 404).
Add content-negotiation tests: call with different Accept headers (missing, */*, application/xml) and validate correct 200/406 responses and Content-Type header consistency.
Standardize and assert error schema: create tests that assert error payload structure (fields, machine-readable codes) in addition to human-readable messages for all error cases.
Expand performance testing: include concurrent requests and longer-running load tests to ensure stable response times and resource usage beyond a one-off large-response timing check.
Add tests for URL-encoding and edge-case path parameters: very long IDs, percent-encoded characters, and multi-byte characters to ensure robust routing and validation.
Consider adding tests for logging/observability and metrics (if in scope): ensure relevant metrics/logs are emitted for successful, error, and degraded responses.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: DELETE /1.0/kb/invoiceItems/{invoiceItemId}/tags - Remove tags from invoice item

covered: Valid Deletion: Multiple scenarios (TC01, TC02, TC03, TC05) verify successful removals returning 204 and empty body.
Non-Existent Resource: TC08 verifies 404 for missing invoice item.
Path Parameter Validation: TC09 checks invalid invoiceItemId format (400).
Required Header Validation: TC10 verifies missing X-Killbill-CreatedBy returns 400.
Authentication: TC11 checks invalid/expired token returns 401.
Query Parameter Variants: TC02, TC05, TC06, TC07, TC13 cover presence/absence, subset, non-present IDs, empty tagDef, extra params, and malformed tagDef UUIDs.
Optional Headers: TC03 covers X-Killbill-Reason and X-Killbill-Comment handling; TC18 covers special characters in comment.
Malformed / Invalid Input: TC13 and TC16 check malformed UUIDs and partially specified tagDef arrays.
Large Input / Limits: TC14 probes very large tagDef lists and expected outcomes (204 or 413).
Security Input Validation: TC15 covers XSS/injection attempts in headers.
Concurrency / Performance: TC17 exercises high concurrency to detect race conditions and performance issues.
Service Availability / Integration Failures: TC12 (service down) and TC19 (audit logging unavailable) test resilience/partial failure responses.
Edge-case: TC04 covers deleting when invoice item has no tags (empty response handling).
Accessibility & Documentation: TC20 addresses documentation and error-message accessibility.
gaps: Soft Delete Behavior: No scenario verifies whether tags are soft-deleted vs permanently removed or asserts the persistent storage state (deleted flag, timestamps, audit entries).
Authorization/Role-Based Access (403): Tests cover authentication (401) but not forbidden scenarios (user authenticated but lacks permission -> 403).
Idempotency / Repeat Deletes: No explicit tests for repeating the same DELETE (idempotent behavior), or deleting tags that were just removed (expected 204 vs 404 ambiguity).
Server Error Handling (5xx): Apart from 503 (TC12), there are no tests that simulate 500/Internal Server Error, DB failures, or graceful degradation patterns.
Error Response Schema and Content-Type: Tests assert presence of error messages but do not validate the error response schema, content-type headers, or consistent error codes/body structure.

HTTP Headers and Response Metadata: No assertions for response headers like Content-Type, Cache-Control, ETag or other relevant metadata (even if caching is less relevant for DELETE, content-type and audit headers matter).

Partial Failure Semantics: While TC19 mentions possible partial failures, there is no concrete test that verifies transactional atomicity when removing multiple tag IDs (e.g., some succeed, some fail) or the exact HTTP status for partial success beyond the broad TC19 note.
Duplicate / Repeated tagDef entries and Ordering: No tests for duplicate UUIDs in tagDef, differently ordered lists, or percent-encoded query params.
Boundary Conditions on Headers: No tests for very long X-Killbill-Comment/Reason values, charset/encoding edge cases beyond special characters/XSS, or limits on header sizes.
Rate limiting / Throttling (429): No tests for request throttling or server-side rate limiting despite performance/concurrency test being present.
recommendations: Add a soft-delete verification test: after DELETE, assert whether tag records are removed or flagged (include DB-level verification or API read-back to confirm permanent vs soft delete).
Add authorization (403) tests: exercise authenticated users without sufficient privileges to confirm 403 responses and correct error messages.
Add idempotency tests: send the same DELETE twice and assert the second call behaves as expected (204 vs 404) and document intended behavior.
Simulate server-side failures (500): create tests that force DB/transaction failures or throw 500 to ensure the API returns meaningful errors and that clients can handle them.
Validate error response schema and headers: assert Content-Type, structured error fields (code/message/type), and consistent formatting across error scenarios (400/401/403/404/500/503).
Add tests for duplicate and percent-encoded tagDef values and ordering to ensure the server normalizes/handles these cases consistently.
Add boundary/header-size tests: very large X-Killbill-Comment/Reason to identify header-size limits and expected error responses.

Add explicit transactional/partial-failure tests: craft scenarios where some tag removals fail (e.g., constrained DB) and assert whether operation is atomic, and check the exact status code and audit logs.
Add rate-limiting/429 tests: simulate many requests in short time windows to assert throttling behavior and proper 429 responses and Retry-After headers.
Add assertions for response metadata: at minimum assert Content-Type and any relevant audit or correlation headers returned by the API so downstream services can rely on them.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: DELETE /1.0/kb/admin/cache/tenants - Invalidates Caches per tenant level

covered: Valid Deletion: Success scenario (TC01) validates successful tenant-level cache invalidation and HTTP 204 response.
Authorization: Missing and invalid authentication are covered (TC02, TC03) to ensure unauthorized access is rejected.
Non-Existent Resource: Non-existent tenant context is tested (TC04) with expected 404.
Server/Error Responses: Internal error, service unavailable, and gateway timeout conditions are covered (TC05, TC06, TC14) mapping to 5xx error handling.
Malformed Requests / Input Validation: Unsupported parameters and malformed requests are addressed (TC07).
Security: Injection/invalid header payload scenario is included (TC08).
Idempotency / Edge Cases: Empty cache case and idempotency are validated (TC09).
Concurrency / Performance: Concurrent requests and response-time expectations are addressed (TC10).
Regression and Integration: Regression validation (TC11) and dependent-service integration observation (TC12) are present.
Partial State Handling: Partially populated cache invalidation is covered (TC13).
gaps: Content-Type / Response Media Type: Acceptance criteria mention producing application/json but tests do not assert Content-Type header or reconcile that with 204 empty body.
Soft Deletes / Persistence Semantics: No tests check whether cache entries are soft-deleted vs permanently removed or how they appear to other persistence layers.
Authorization Granularity / Forbidden (403): Role/permission-based authorization (403) for authenticated but unauthorized admin contexts is not explicitly tested.
Partial Failure / Partial Success: No scenario where cache invalidation succeeds for some shards/nodes and fails for others (partial failures) and how API surfaces partial results.
Rate Limiting / Throttling: No tests for rate limiting, throttling, or handling of too many requests in a short window.
Response Headers & Caching Metadata: No assertions for caching-related headers (e.g., Cache-Control, ETag) or cache-invalidation notifications/events.

Input Format / Tenant Context Variations: Tests do not validate malformed or missing tenant-context headers formatting (beyond non-existent tenant), or multi-tenant boundary checks (attempt to invalidate another tenant).
Observability / Audit Logging: No checks for audit logs, request tracing IDs, or metrics emitted for invalidation operations.
Large-Scale / Resource Limits: No tests for very large caches, memory/CPU impact, or long-running invalidations beyond timeout scenario (only TC14).
recommendations: Assert response media type and headers: Add checks that the API sets Content-Type (application/json) when applicable, or explicitly document/verify that 204 responses are intentionally body-less and how clients should interpret Content-Type.
Add authorization-granularity tests: Include scenarios for authenticated but unauthorized users (403), and tests that ensure an admin scoped to tenant A cannot invalidate tenant B's cache.

Test partial-failure behavior: Create scenarios where some cache nodes fail during invalidation and assert the API returns a clear status (partial success vs full failure) and appropriate HTTP code/messages.
Add rate-limiting tests: Verify behavior when many requests arrive in short succession (throttle, 429 responses, retry-after header).
Validate tenant-context formatting and missing headers: Add negative tests for malformed tenant header/token formats and missing tenant-context when authentication is present.
